oai_dc:dc.dc:title: RELATIVE SEA LEVEL RISE PROJECTIONS BY 2150 AND FLOODING HAZARD ALONG THE COASTS OF THE MEDITERRANEAN SEA
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Anzidei, Marco
Vecchio, Antonio
Serpelloni, Enrico
Alberti, Tommaso
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sea level rise is one of the main global threats caused by global warming. Recent studies and IPCC reports (www.ipcc.ch) show that global sea levels could rise up to 1.0 m by 2100 and near 1.5 m by 2150. Instabilities of west Antarctica and Greenland ice sheets could lead to higher sea level rises than expected today. We used IPCC data from the AR6 Report to estimate relative sea level rise projections and flooding scenarios for different socio economic climate pathways for 2030- 2050-2100-2150 in the Mediterranean region.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Coastal Engineering Proceedings; No. 38 (2024): Proceedings of 38th Conference on Coastal Engineering, Rome, Italy, 2024; management.247
